messages.message: Question: Are we able to "clone" an application to use as a starting point for a new app? This was asked by a partner, who envisions needing multiple variants of the same, but would want to have the same base set of fields across the apps, with only slight variations of questions/prompts. @avi @Varun Jain

Good feedback! @ChrisM I think they would need to clone the build project rather than clone the app. From the build project, they would then be able to edit what they need and publish an app.

Adding in @Bastiane @Eric Han

This is good feedback. Agree with Hannah that ideally they would clone the build project v/s the app since they'd be able to edit the version there. @Bastiane @Eric Han is this something that you're already considering? If not, should we consider for Q1?

For apps, we should support multiple versions, but these are intended to be incremental v/s testing variants. Supporting multiple versions was considered for Q4 but didn't make the cut (JIRA) (https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-170).

Cloning a project has some security implications but I think in all cases if a user has access to an app, it means they implicitly should be able to access the source project already? Are there cases where this isn't true? We can perhaps have apps be published as default "open source" so their source projects are clonable. But allow for a toggle if the author doesn't want to share the source

I think in this case, the user is the app publisher and they have access to the app and source project. They want to create a variant of the app and retain the original app too. The neatest way for the app publisher to do this feels like:
• Keep original project and app
• Clone original project, make changes, publish new app
This ability to clone the build project should only be accessible for the creator of the build project (maybe also someone that has edit access to it in an org).
